Questions.QuestionString: 32. Gust Load Alleviation Function in a FLY BY WIRE system. (Level 2)

B. is achieved by the weight saving from elimination of cables, feel units and other

C. may be controlled by the elevators.

Questions.QuestionString: 33. Powered flying control actuators. (Level 2)

36. Q feel units use. (Level 2)

Questions.QuestionString:
38. In an aircraft flying control system employing servo-tabs, the installation of external
ground locks to the main control surface. (Level 3)
Answers: A. would not prevent movement of the control column.

B. is unnecessary since the system is irreversible and therefore the control surface cannot be
displaced by the wind.
C. would also prevent movement of the control column.

Questions.QuestionString: 39. When the primary stops fitted to a control run have been contacted. (Level 3)
Answers: A. a clearance exists at the secondary stops.
B. the secondary stops have been over-ridden.
C. the secondary stops will just be in contact.

Questions.QuestionString:
40. A universal protractor used to measure degrees of aileron travel should be zeroed.
(Level 3)
Answers: A. when the aircraft is in level flight attitude.
B. with the aileron in the neutral position.
C. with the aileron in the down position.

Questions.QuestionString: 41. A flying control static friction check. (Level 3)
Answers: A. can only be carried out during flight.

B. demonstrates the force the pilot requires to overcome system inertia and move the
controls.
C. will demonstrate that a high force is always necessary to operate non-powered controls.

Questions.QuestionString:
42. With the elevator trim wheel adjusted fully aft. (nose up), range of movement of the

Answers: A. would make no difference to the movement.

Questions.QuestionString:
43. In normal flight, if the control wheel is moved to the left, then the aileron on the right

B. increase the angle of attack of the right hand wing.
C. keep the angle of attack of the right wing constant.

Questions.QuestionString: 44. To avoid moments bending the root of the wing, the aircraft will be fitted with. (Level 3)

Questions.QuestionString:
45. In an aircraft system employing balance tabs, the installation of external ground locks

B. is unnecessary since the system is irreversible.

Questions.QuestionString: 46. Autotrim will switch to 'slow' when. (Level 1)

49. In a fully Fly By Wire Aircraft, ground spoilers are deployed automatically when the

Questions.QuestionString:

Questions.QuestionString: 51. What is the purpose of a differential Frise aileron?. (Level 3)
Answers: A. To decrease the drag and decrease the rate of yaw and turn.
B. Has no effect on rate of yaw and turn.
C. To increase the drag to increase the rate of yaw and turn.

Questions.QuestionString: 52. An artificial feel system is necessary in a powered flying control system to. (Level 3)
Answers: A. increasing the sensitivity of the control system.

C. prevent overloading of the power control units.

Questions.QuestionString:
53. In the event of hydraulic failure in a power control system, a requirement of the manual

Answers: A. operated by the standby hydraulic system.

Questions.QuestionString: 55. As a consequence of the C of G being close to its aft limit. (Level 3)

C. the stick forces will be high in fore and aft pitch, due to the high longitudinal stability.

Questions.QuestionString:

B. use of the rudder control.

Questions.QuestionString: 177. A series type yaw damper. (Level 2)
Answers: A. moves the rudder and the ailerons to damp out Dutch roll.
B. moves the rudder pedals and the rudder.

Questions.QuestionString: 178. An interrupter arm incorporated in a flying control locking mechanism. (Level 2)
Answers: A. locks the ailerons and elevators.

Questions.QuestionString: 182. The outboard ailerons on some aircraft. (Level 2)

B. are isolated to prevent aileron reversal.
C. are isolated to improve sensitivity.

Questions.QuestionString: 183. Pushing the left rudder pedal. (Level 2)
Answers: A. yaws the aircraft left and possibly the right wing will rise.

Questions.QuestionString: 186. With respect to flight spoilers, they.

Questions.QuestionString: 204. The purpose of cable tension regulators is to
Answers: A. Keep tension of the cable roughly constant at different temperatures

Questions.QuestionString: 210. On a full fly-by-wire system, a speedbrake screwjack servomotor is controlled by the
Answers: C. Flight management and guidance computer.

212. Mass balance weights are used to

Answers: A. For power assisted control systems.

Questions.QuestionString: 215. A stick shaker is a device which
Answers: A. Helps extricate an aircraft from soft ground.
B. Gives a short period of extra lift to assist take off.
C. Vibrates the control column near stalling speed.

Questions.QuestionString: 216. Ruddervators when moved, will move
Answers: A. Either opposite each other or together, depending on the selection.
C. Opposite to each other only.

Answers: B. Air loads on the control surfaces.

Questions.QuestionString: 218. Spoiler panels are controlled by
Answers: A. The aileron control wheel and speed brake lever.
B. A speed brake lever only.
C. The aileron control wheel only.

Questions.QuestionString: 219. "If hydraulic pressure is removed from a spoiler system, the spoiler panels
Answers: A. Go to down if any are not already down.

Questions.QuestionString: 220. Moving the elevator control columns fully aft, then the
Answers: A. Aircraft tends to go nose down.
B. Aircraft tends to go nose up.
C. Aircraft tends to roll to the right.

Answers: A. Increase wing loading on take-off.
B. Prevent FOD ingestion into the engines on landing and taxiing.
C. Dump the lift and increase the drag

Answers: A. Yaws the aircraft left and possibly the right wing will rise.
C. No effect on the aircraft.

Questions.QuestionString: 223. Differential aileron control will
Answers: A. Prevent yawing in conjunction with rudder input.
B. Cause a nose down moment.

B. Prevents extreme wing bending during gusts

Questions.QuestionString: 226. To avoid moments bending the root of the wing, the aircraft will be fitted with
Answers: C. Automatic trim control for controlled turns and rudder movements.

Questions.QuestionString: 227. An artificial feel system is necessary in a powered flying control system to
Answers: A. Increasing the sensitivity of the control system.
B. Provide the pilot with simulated stick forces.
C. Prevent overloading of the power control units.

Questions.QuestionString:
228. In normal flight, if the control wheel is moved to the left, then the aileron on the right
wing will

229. In a fully Fly By Wire Aircraft, ground spoilers are deployed automatically when the
aircraft is on ground and
Answers: C. Weight on ground switch is activated.

Questions.QuestionString: 230. When the control column is moved back and the hand-wheel turned to the left
Answers: A. The elevators move down and the left aileron moves down.
B. The left aileron moves up and the elevators move up.
C. The elevators move up and the left aileron moves down.

Questions.QuestionString: 231. Load alleviation function in turbulent weather conditions will result in
Answers: C. Ailerons and spoiler moving symmetrically upward.

Questions.QuestionString: 232. The two switches for pitch trim are located
Answers: A. On the captain’s and the first officer’s control wheels acting like an 'AND' switch.
B. On the control column with the captain having priority over the First Officer.
C. On the control column acting like an 'OR' switch.

Questions.QuestionString: 233. What is the purpose of a differential aileron?.
Answers: A. To decrease the drag and decrease the rate of yaw and turn.
B. Has no effect on rate of yaw and turn.
C. To increase the drag to increase the rate of yaw and turn.

Questions.QuestionString:
234. What is fitted on the aircraft to enable the pilot to reduce his speed rapidly in event of
severe turbulence, or speed tending to rise above the Never Exceed Limit?.
235. A differential aileron control system results in.
Answers: A. Aileron drag being reduced on the inner wing in a turn.
B. Aileron drag being compensated by small rudder movements.
C. Aileron drag being reduced on the outer wing in a turn.

Questions.QuestionString: 236. A differential aileron control is one which gives.
Answers: A. A larger aileron up travel than down.
B. The down-going aileron more travel than the up-going one.
C. Equal aileron travel in each direction, but variable for stick movement.

Questions.QuestionString: 237. A stick shaker.
Answers: A. Is a linear actuator attached to the base of the control column.
B. Is an electric motor and mounted on the control column.
C. Vibrates the elevators to cause buffeting of the airframe.

Questions.QuestionString: 238. If the side stick is moved forward and to the left.
Answers: A. Left aileron moves down, right aileron up, elevator down.
B. Left aileron moves up, right aileron down, elevator down.
C. Left aileron moves up, right aileron moves down, elevator up.

Questions.QuestionString: 239. On an aircraft fitted with spoilers for lateral control, roll to the right is caused by.
Answers: A. Left spoiler extending, right spoiler remaining retracted.
B. Right spoiler extending, left spoiler remaining retracted.

245. What happens when a control stick is pulled back and to the left?
Answers: A. Elevator up, left aileron down.
B. Elevator down, right aileron down.
C. Elevator up, right aileron down.
